channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Malaysian Opposition Leader Sentenced in Sodomy Case
item.description: An appeals court gave Anwar Ibrahim a five-year term a week before he was expected to register for elections.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Malaysia's opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, met his supporters as he left the court building in Putrajaya, outside Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday.

item.title: Off the Charts: A New Cold War Would Differ From the Old
item.description: Unlike the Soviet Union, today’s Russia has substantial trade ties with Western Europe, and it and the West are more dependent on each other than they were in decades past.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD NORRIS

item.title: Ukraine Won’t Boycott Paralympics in Russia
item.description: Ukraine said on Friday that it would compete in the Paralympics instead of withdrawing in protest of Russia’s intervention in the Crimean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SHPIGEL

item.title: India Ink: A Rare Government Success Story for Women’s Empowerment in Kerala
item.description: From a few thousand women, the Kudumbashree program in the southwestern state of Kerala has grown into a giant community enterprise with 3.7 million members.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: A Kudumbashree worker involved in community farming near the Kerala village of Kadakkanad. Around 260,000 workers currently till and harvest more than 60,000 acres throughout the state.

item.title: Congo Warlord's Conviction Brings Relief to International Court
item.description: Congolese warlord Germain Katanga was convicted on Friday of being an accessory to war crimes including murder and pillage - only the second conviction in the 12-year history of the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Detain Government Employee in Beating of Nurse
item.description: The police in Nanjing have detained a government employee after a video of the beating of a nurse generated widespread outrage online.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: India Ink: In Kolkata, Reminders of Why We Help the ‘Last Girl’
item.description: To the women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem, the bright, hopeful youths from the red-light district illustrate the need to follow Gandhi’s standard of making a difference in the life of the weakest.
item.dc:creator: By RUCHIRA GUPTA
item.media:description: The women's rights activist Gloria Steinem, third from right, with students in front of the Victoria Memorial in Kolkata.

item.title: Kerry Arrives in Jordan on Mideast Peace Mission
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry was due to discuss a plan that would set the parameters for a treaty between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Malaysian Opposition Leader Is Sentenced
item.description: Malaysia’s state news agency says an appeals court has found opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim guilty on sodomy charges, overturning his earlier acquittal.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russians Back Secession of Crimea and Pressure Kiev
item.description: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said on Friday they would embrace a vote by Crimea to break away from Ukraine, while Gazprom, the Russian energy company, warned it may shut off exports over a $1.89 billion payment.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russia protesters got off a police bus in Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, on Thursday and were greeted by supporters, who had forced the police to release them.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Censors Hit Delete on a Party Chief’s Censorship Remarks
item.description: It seems that comments on microblogs about Internet censorship, even by senior Communist Party officials, can fall prey to China’s army of online minders.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Zhang Chunxian, Communist Party secretary of Xinjiang, was questioned by reporters on Thursday about the recent stabbing attack in Kunming.

item.title: Lens Blog: Venezuela in Black-and-White
item.description: Though famed for chromatic installations, Carlos Cruz-Diez was first taken by the magic of light as a young photographer documenting Venezuela’s emergence as a modern state.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Los Diablos de Yare. San Francisco de Yare, Estado Miranda, Venezuela. 1951.

item.title: Turkish Prime Minister Threatens to Ban Facebook and YouTube
item.description: Audio recordings of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s alleged conversations suggesting corruption have been leaked in the past weeks.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Adding Elders and Children to a Domestic Violence Law
item.description: As a proposed law against domestic violence slowly works its way through the legislative process, a scholar and deputy to the National People’s Congress says it must include protections for the elderly and children, as well as spouses.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sun Xiaomei, National People's Congress delegate.

item.title: U.S. Seems Unlikely to Accept That Rights Treaty Applies to Its Actions Abroad
item.description: A panel in Geneva disagrees with the position of the United States that it has no obligations under a global rights treaty when operating abroad.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: India Ink: How to Woo Muslim Voters in Uttar Pradesh
item.description: Gaining the support of Muslims in the politically important state requires a more complex strategy than just fielding a candidate of the same religion.
item.dc:creator: By SONIA PAUL
item.media:description: Men cheering for Narendra Modi, the prime ministerial candidate of Bharatiya Janata Party, at his rally in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, on March 2.

item.title: India Ink: To Change India’s Preference for Sons, Start With the Women
item.description: The author of “Gender Equality and Inequality in Rural India: Blessed With a Son” says her studies show that using education and employment to help girls get on an equal footing with sons would help reduce gender bias.
item.dc:creator: By CAROL VLASSOFF
item.media:description: Carol Vlassoff is an adjunct professor in the department of epidemiology and community medicine at the University of Ottawa.

item.title: 'Beethoven of Japan' Apologizes for 'Causing Trouble With My Lies'
item.description: Mamoru Samuragochi admitted that he was not legally deaf and apologized for hiring a ghostwriter since the 1990s to compose most of his music.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Russia Experts See Thinning Ranks’ Effect on U.S. Policy
item.description: With the end of the Cold War, Russia ceased being a concentration of choice among future foreign policy professionals. The dearth is being felt now.
item.dc:creator: By JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: U.S. Seems Unlikely to Accept That Rights Treaty Applies to Its Actions Abroad
item.description: A panel in Geneva disagrees with the position of the United States that it has no obligations under a global rights treaty when operating abroad.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: World Briefing: Turkish Court Backs General’s Appeal
item.description: The Constitutional Court on Thursday ruled in favor of a former army chief who was appealing the legality of his initial detention in 2012 in a case that resulted in his conviction and life sentence last year for plotting a coup against the government, according to a written statement posted on the court’s website.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing: Iran Disputes Israeli Arms Claim
item.description: Iran accused Israel on Thursday of falsifying claims that it had seized an Iranian shipment of weapons bound for Palestinian militants in Gaza aboard a merchant ship.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Listening Post: With Netanyahu, Obama Plays Bad Cop to Kerry’s Good Cop
item.description: President Obama has fixed ideas about how best to pursue peace in the Middle East, and a far less solicitous style than his secretary of state, John Kerry.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel held a meeting with President Obama in the Oval Office on Monday.

item.title: Canadian Oil Will Take New Route Across U.S.
item.description: A pipeline through which oil once flowed west will instead take diluted bitumen and conventional oil from western Canada to Montreal, traversing the United States in the process.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Decades After London Racial Killing, Inquiry Shows Police Spied on Victim’s Parents
item.description: As a family campaigned for a thorough murder investigation, an undercover officer was recording the details of their personal lives, progress and decisions.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
